data.title: A Little Thing Called Love (2010)
data.meta_description: Nam is an ordinary, unattractive 14-year-old girl secretly in love with a popular boy in school named Shone. Wanting to catch his attention, she tries various ways to get close to him. Will Shone notice her efforts? The flush of youth comes with all its awkwardness and insecurities, and there's really nothing like a crazy little thing called love.
data.text:
The Thais know something about longing. They capture it well on film. The mad surging, the illusion of nobility in denial, the perfect — if short-lived — happiness of catching a glance, a smile, or a touch from the beloved. Which is to say I have finally managed to catch Puttipong Pormsaka Na-Sakonnakorn and Wasin Pokpong’s สิ่งเล็กเล็ก ที่เรียกว่า..รัก [A Little Thing Called Love, 2010] … egged on by the sheer popularity of the film among girls (and women) around me who are normally of the even-keeled sort but have been reduced to hysterics by the Tagalog-dubbed version of this film which aired in a network TV station a few months back.

Watching it, I understand the passion of the fans.…

This is a coming of age flick about a schoolgirl’s “first love”. Apparently this was a very popular film in China back then and many Chinese fans stan the main 2 characters till now.

Initially the movie made me uncomfortable — firstly because fair skin is associated with beauty. The main character undergoes the typical transformation you see in chick flicks: short hair becomes long, black hair becomes brown, irises become brown... and tan skin becomes fair. And it’s about how a crush becomes a motivating factor for a girl to improve on herself — change her appearance, get good grades — before he takes notice of her.

So I didn’t approve of the apparent message of the movie, that…
